data.name: Text0_1
data.value: When we think or hear about a certain company, the first couple of things that come to our minds is the logo of such company, its products and/or services, and sometimes their target market or where is the closest outlet.

data.name: Text0_2
data.value: However, if we’re working within the company in lower ranks, we also think about our colleagues, boss, and why the coffee machine is still not working.

data.name: Text0_3
data.value: The boss and higher managers reflect about those things as well, but additionally, they consider how to improve the situation of the company, whether it is sales, production or the work environment.

data.name: Text0_4
data.value: For that, a company needs to come up with an idea.

data.name: Text0_5
data.value: At first glance, coming up with an idea does not seem so difficult. While some people would agree with that, we still need to keep in mind a couple of factors.

data.name: Text0_6
data.value: A company that has been on the market for good couple years may struggle with coming up with a new and effective idea.

data.name: Text0_7
data.value: There are many ways and tools that help us with generating and managing ideas, depending on the goals and size of such ideas. One of the ways which I’ll be talking about is crowdsourcing.

data.name: Text1
data.value: For those of you who don’t know what crowdsourcing is…

data.name: Text1_1
data.value: As the name says by itself, Crowdsourcing is a method that is based on gathering (sourcing) knowledge or other resources from a group of people (the crowd).

data.name: Text1_2
data.value: It is a quite convenient way of collecting goods or ideas, because the crowd doesn’t have to be consisted of people solely working within our company. Crowdsourcing allows people from outside of the company to participate.

data.name: Text1_3
data.value: There are different types of crowdsourcing, one of the main ones are:

data.name: Text1_4
data.value: Crowdfunding

data.name: Text1_5
data.value: Crowdvoting

data.name: Text1_6
data.value: Crowdcontest

data.name: Text2
data.value: Let’s talk about the advantages of using Crowdsourcing

data.name: Text2_1
data.value: The crowd

data.name: Text2_1_1
data.value: As mentioned before, the crowd is composed of many people. Whether they’re inside or outside of our company, they provide us with a wide range of knowledge and ideas, especially those people from outside, because it’s them who can pinpoint the flaws or lack of some things in our business, that stops us from improving.

data.name: Text2_1_2
data.value: Furthermore, every person has a different attitude, level of knowledge, etc.

data.name: Text2_1_3
data.value: Of course, it does not mean that 1 person = 1 unique idea. Some individuals may think of the same thing, but overall, crowdsourcing can fill us with a decent amount of ideas.

data.name: Text2_2
data.value: The speed and cost

data.name: Text2_2_1
data.value: Surely, crowdsourcing takes time, however in comparison to other methods, it is still one of the fastest methods.

data.name: Text2_2_2
data.value: It not only saves time but also money, because the company doesn’t need to create and fund a specialist project or team. The only thing that needs to be done is some type of internet service: a website or a mobile app, which would enable the participants to send their ideas.

data.name: Text3
data.value: As for the disadvantages of Crowdsourcing

data.name: Text3_1
data.value: Not precise

data.name: Text3_1_1
data.value: Even though the amount of ideas seems promising, we need to remember that some people in the crowd may not know much about our company or even about its existence. It is both a good and a bad thing, because while we might get a fresh idea and get to know the view and opinion from a person who’s not familiar with our company, we still have to take into consideration that the idea might not have the things we’re looking for.

data.name: Text3_2
data.value: Not prepared

data.name: Text3_2_1
data.value: A further drawback also refers to the amount of ideas.

data.name: Text3_2_2
data.value: While our company receives ideas in a fast pace, we need to be prepared to evaluate them. The amount depends on the size of the company and/or the crowd, the bigger one of those is, the bigger the amount (in most cases).

data.name: Text3_2_3
data.value: If our company does not have a good team responsible for evaluation of ideas, the speed advantage of crowdsourcing can be backfired due to the slow evaluation processes in the company.

data.name: Text4
data.value: One of the platforms that uses crowdsourcing is “InnoCentive”

data.name: Text4_1
data.value: InnoCentive has helped many businesses, governments and charities since 2001. In 2020, it was acquired by Wazoku, another innovative business founded in 2011.

data.name: Text4_2
data.value: Both organisations believe that innovation is a very important factor in any business, so they help those businesses in delivering innovation and building a culture of innovation.

data.name: Text4_3
data.value:
InnoCentive provides us with a very clear website.
There are:

data.name: Text4_4
data.value: “Challenges” – current problems of various companies

data.name: Text4_5
data.value: “Seekers” or “Pavilions” - companies which seek for a solution to their problems

data.name: Text4_6
data.value: “Solvers” – individuals who can send their ideas to the problems

data.name: Text4_7
data.value:
In InnoCentive there are companies from many sectors: from ‘Food’ to ‘Technology’.
In “Pavilions” section, we can browse through the companies that use InnoCentive, such like “NASA” or “U.S. Air Force”.

data.name: Text5
data.value: How does it work?

data.name: Text5_1
data.value: If we want to search for a problem that a company struggles with, we simply go to “Challenges”.

data.name: Text5_10
data.value: Once submitted, the only thing that is left is to wait for the company to evaluate all received ideas and the announcement of the winner.

data.name: Text5_2
data.value: From there, we can:

data.name: Text5_3
data.value: Check the latest challenges

data.name: Text5_4
data.value: Go to already mentioned “Pavilions” where we can look for challenges from a particular company we’re interested in

data.name: Text5_5
data.value: Browse through all available challenges

data.name: Text5_6
data.value:
Each challenge can be of a different type, such like:
‘ideation’ where it is a simple idea or ‘theoretical’ where the idea is not yet a proof of concept, so the Solver needs to give a full description of the idea to become an actual product or service. We can also transfer the intellectual property and rights of our already existing patent.

data.name: Text5_7
data.value: What is worth mentioning is that each challenge has an award to win: a money prize (the most common) or collaboration with a company posting the challenge.

data.name: Text5_8
data.value: This definitely encourages people to dive into innovative thinking and trying to come up with ideas and possible solutions to the challenges.

data.name: Text5_9
data.value:
Usually, the money prize is for the podium – the first 3 winners. The company decides what amount each place gets.
However, every challenge has a deadline, which spices things up, because it raises our adrenaline a bit, reason being the pressure of time. Of course, there’s enough time, so that everyone actively interested has enough time to think of an idea, work on it, and submit it.

data.name: Text6
data.value: Another example of a platform is “Lean Action Plan”

data.name: Text6_1
data.value: While it is not entirely focused on crowdsourcing, I still wanted to show the similarity between those 2 examples.

data.name: Text6_10
data.value: Moreover, the workshops are focused on production processes, so even if an employee comes up with an idea to improve other sector of the company, the coordinator of the workshop wouldn’t really accept the idea, since it’s not in its field of activity.

data.name: Text6_2
data.value: Lean Action Plan offers a wide range of services of diagnosis, consultancy, projects and workshops regarding business processes.

data.name: Text6_3
data.value: I’ll be focusing on one of the workshops called “Kaizen”.

data.name: Text6_4
data.value: Kaizen focuses on constant improvement and explains how even small ideas can bring big effects with time. The workshop teaches the employees what is the value in production process and how to detect obstacles within the process.

data.name: Text6_5
data.value: My brother works in a company where the Kaizen is implemented. After the workshops, the employees are encouraged to think of ideas that could improve the production process within their company.

data.name: Text6_6
data.value: As mentioned before, <u>it’s not a typical crowdsourcing</u>. The workshops give knowledge and teach methods, but still have some elements of crowdsourcing.

data.name: Text6_7
data.value:
Similar to InnoCentive, the best ideas are awarded.
Employees can submit their ideas on the production improvement, as long as they think it might be beneficial for the efficiency of production.

data.name: Text6_8
data.value:
In case of the company my brother’s working in, around every quarter, the gathered ideas are being evaluated by Kaizen. The podium (first 3 places) wins the prize. The prizes are funded by the company, and these are products and services worth a particular amount of money.
For example, the prizes are worth: $500, $400, $300 for the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place respectfully. The winners get to choose the product or service from the prize pool.

data.name: Text6_9
data.value: What differentiates the workshop from crowdsourcing is that the employees don’t think for a solution to a sudden problem a company is facing, but rather have free will. They can think of anything that could help the production process, anytime.

data.name: Text7
data.value: To summarize

data.name: Text7_1
data.value:
Crowdsourcing is a method for gathering ideas.
It can quickly provide us a big wave of ideas that come from a group people within and outside of our company.

data.name: Text7_2
data.value: While some ideas might not be good and it takes some time to evaluate all of the ideas, the advantages definitely reward us with a solution to our problem.

data.name: Text7_3
data.value: When it comes to platforms like InnoCentive, people have a chance to win some money or collaboration with a company posting its problem.

data.name: Text7_4
data.value: Crowdsourcing gathers all people who think innovatively and depicts how big and important innovation is in businesses. It also shows that every person has a great potential and how crucial it is to listen to the voices of people within and outside of our company.

data.name: Title
data.value: The power of employees and people
